awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantifying the amount and functional significance of long-term stored-water in trees
awd_abstract_narration:
Accurate modeling of water storage and fluxes in both natural and human-altered ecosystems is critical to managing global water resources under current-day and projected future climates. One important step towards accurate modeling involves determining how much water trees store, and how the amount of stored water varies through time and within tree organs.  Another important step involves determining how stored water, and variations in stored water, affect the physiological behavior of individual trees and larger ecosystems. The investigators in this project will measure the amount of water stored in different organs of trees, determine how long water resides in these organs, and evaluate how long-term stored water affects whole-tree water use. The data collected will reveal novel information about how trees store and manage water, which will ultimately allow prediction of tree water storage and water movement through ecosystems in current and future climates. The study site in Idaho broadly represents many landscapes across the Intermountain West. Results from this study will be shared with local communities in the Snake River Plain region, and activities will involve students and faculty members from Tribal Colleges in the Pacific Northwest.

Most models assume steady-state water flow through the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum. However, there is substantial storage of water in trees, and the residence times of water inside trees ranges from days to months. The total amount of stored water in trees and broader ecosystems, how long water resides in plants, and the ecohydrological implications of tree water storage are still not completely understood. Characterizing the duration of water storage and its impacts on tree ecohydrology are critical for improving hydrological models.  The data collected in this study will be used to test the hypotheses that: (1) Water is stored in trees for many days, with differences in residence time correlating to species- and size-specific sapwood architecture and water-management strategies; (2) Stored water will buffer declines in water transport as soil moisture availability declines, at daily and seasonal timescales; (3) Inter-species differences in water storage and transport-buffering strategies will translate to differential responses in whole-tree water balance and fluxes due to changing climate in modeled scenarios. The work combines stable isotope tracers (deuterium), gas exchange, and hydraulic functional trait data collected in the field with process- and trait-based modeling to determine residence times of water in tree organs, how trees manage water storage and transport among organs, and how water storage regulates whole-tree water relations at hourly to monthly timescales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding water storage and fluxes in both natural and human-altered ecosystems is critical to managing global water resources under present and future climates. Part of this effort involves research to better understand how stored water - and variations in stored water - affect the physiology of individual trees and water cycling at the ecosystem level. To that end, researchers developed and tested a novel method of studying water storage and transport inside of living trees at field sites in different parts of the United States. The method combines fieldwork involving stable isotope tracers and precision borehole observations with numerical analysis of breakthrough curves, which show how tracers move and disperse within flow systems. In this case, researchers used 99.9% enriched deuterated water as a tracer, which they injected directly into the trunks of trees that were instrumented for intensive measurements. Researchers developed breakthrough curves by analyzing water vapor collected from boreholes that were screened to isolate specific tree tissues (e.g., sapwood, heartwood) at various heights along the branchless (below canopy) portion of the trunk.

Researchers tested the new method during three collaborative field campaigns that took place in North Carolina and Idaho between 2021 and 2023.  Each campaign involved personnel from Duke University, Idaho State University, and the University of Georgia. Two of the field campaigns collected and examined breakthrough curves using once-daily measurements from tracer injection experiments in multiple trees. The field campaigns focused on specific gymnosperms: loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) and Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii); and specific angiosperms: southern red oak (Quercus falcata) and trembling aspen (Populus tremuloides). These two field studies yielded breakthrough curves from three distinct tissue depths (shallow sapwood, deep sapwood, and heartwood) and at least three different heights along the trunk of each tree. A third field campaign collected higher frequency observations from tracer injected into a single loblolly pine tree and yielded breakthrough curves with sub-daily resolution for multiple heights and tissue depths.  During each field campaign, researchers combined the new borehole method with additional ecophysiological measurements that included sap flux, tree volumetric water content, bulk leaf water isotopes, and ancillary meteorological observations.

Across all species and field sites, shallow sapwood yielded the most prominent tracer breakthrough curves, although researchers observed breakthrough curves and other signs of tracer enrichment at all trunk heights and tissue depths. The degree of radial tracer movement (i.e., movement from sapwood into heartwood) differed among tree species.  Thus, while sapwood and heartwood water storage are hydraulically connected, the degree of connectivity varies among species. Field campaigns also revealed large differences in tracer transport rates and residence times among species. Ongoing work seeks to interpret these differences using a variation of the StorAge Selection model - a hydrological model designed for catchment studies but adapted to examine water movement in trees.  Overall, the methods developed through this project open the door for more detailed in situ studies of water movement and storage within trees.  

The project provided hands-on training in field methods, laboratory techniques, and computational analyses for an early career researcher as well as graduate and undergraduate students. Trainees learned to incorporate cutting edge technologies (e.g., laser spectroscopy) into novel methods designed to answer questions about tree water use.  Trainees learned to work as team members on large, collaborative field experiments, and they gained experience communicating their work via conference presentations and publications. The project also provided a unique opportunity for researchers to introduce students and faculty to water isotope concepts and methods during two workshops at the Fifth Geoscience Alliance Conference in Minneapolis, Minnesota.  More than twenty workshop participants, who mainly comprised tribal college students and faculty, analyzed their own water samples in a laboratory using laser spectroscopy. Participants later attended a follow-up workshop where they analyzed the resulting dataset.
